entries.title: Singapore PM strips Singh of Leader of Opposition post
entries.snippet:
On January 15, 2026, Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong removed Pritam Singh from his position as Leader of the Opposition following Singh's conviction for lying to parliament. This unprecedented move came after a parliamentary vote declared Singh's conduct "dishonourable and unbecoming," deeming him unsuitable for the role. Wong emphasized the importance of maintaining the rule of law and parliamentary integrity.

Although the Leader of the Opposition role is not constitutionally mandated, it grants extra privileges, such as allowances, staff support, and access to confidential information. Wong has asked the Workers' Party to propose a replacement untainted by the scandal. Despite his removal from the post, Singh will remain a Member of Parliament and leader of the Workers' Party.

The conviction stems from Singh giving false testimony in 2021 regarding a former party member's fabricated parliamentary speech. Singh had become Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election. While political observers downplayed the practical impact of Singh’s removal, the Workers’ Party stated it will carefully consider Wong's request before responding.

entries.title: Singapore parliament to debate removing Leader of the Opposition after lying conviction
entries.snippet: Singapore's Parliament is set to debate the removal of Pritam Singh from his role as Leader of the Opposition following his conviction for lying to Parliament. The motion, introduced by Leader of the House and People’s Action Party (PAP) MP Indranee Rajah, cites Singh's "dishonourable and unbecoming" behavior as grounds for disqualification. Singh, who became Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election, was found guilty in 2025 of providing false testimony to a parliamentary committee in relation to a fellow Workers' Party member, Raeesah Khan. Although he received fines that allowed him to retain his parliamentary seat, an unsuccessful appeal resulted in Parliament now considering a response to his actions. Indranee stated that such behavior must not be tolerated in Singapore, emphasizing integrity in leadership. The conduct of Workers' Party leaders Sylvia Lim and Faisal Manap is also under scrutiny in connection to Singh’s case. The ruling PAP continues its dominance in Parliament, having won 87 out of 97 seats in the 2025 general election.

entries.title: Singapore court finds opposition party leader guilty of lying to parliament
entries.snippet: On February 17, 2025, a Singapore court found Pritam Singh, the leader of the opposition Workers' Party, guilty of two counts of lying to a parliamentary committee. The charges relate to his 2021 testimony regarding fellow party member Raeesah Khan, who admitted to making false statements in parliament. Singh claimed he had advised Khan to come clean, but Judge Luke Tan cited substantial witness testimony contradicting Singh, including a remark suggesting the incident should be taken "to the grave." Singh, who pleaded not guilty, faces a sentencing decision later the same day. A fine over S$10,000 or a jail term longer than one year would disqualify him from participating in the general election scheduled for later this year. This ruling arrives ahead of Prime Minister Lawrence Wong’s first election since taking office and a day before he is due to deliver a national budget speech. The Workers' Party, despite making gains in the 2020 election, has since faced credibility issues due to internal scandals.

parts:
Yes. On **15 Jan 2026**, Prime Minister **Lawrence Wong** ended **Pritam Singh’s** designation as **Leader of the Opposition (LO)** with immediate effect, after Parliament voted that he was unsuitable to continue in the role following his convictions for lying to a parliamentary committee. citeturn5news31turn5news32

A small wording tweak: what PM Wong referred to was the **Committee of Privileges (COP)** (a parliamentary committee), not a **Commission of Inquiry (COI)**. In his letter/statement, he said the Workers’ Party’s nominee should be an **elected MP** who **“should not have been implicated in the earlier findings of the COP”** and must meet the standards expected of the office. citeturn3view0turn5search1

## Likely replacements from the Workers’ Party (given PM Wong’s COP constraint)
Political analysts cited **four** plausible successors who (i) are current WP MPs and (ii) are not the ones publicly flagged as implicated by the COP-linked developments: citeturn3view0

1) **Gerald Giam (Aljunied GRC)**  
   Often described as a frontrunner: experienced, high parliamentary visibility, and part of WP’s leadership structure (Head of Policy Research). citeturn3view0turn4view0

2) **Dennis Tan (Hougang SMC)**  
   Also frequently named a frontrunner: long-tenured parliamentarian, strong Hougang base, and sits on WP’s senior party structure (Organising Secretary; on the Central Executive Committee). citeturn3view0turn4view0

3) **He Ting Ru (Sengkang GRC)**  
   Named by analysts as a possible pick, partly because she holds a senior party office (Party Treasurer) and has parliamentary experience. citeturn3view0

4) **Jamus Lim (Sengkang GRC)**  
   Another analyst-mentioned option: active and vocal in Parliament; also holds a party policy leadership role (Deputy Head for Policy Research). citeturn3view0

## Who is effectively ruled out by the “implicated” condition?
- **Sylvia Lim** is explicitly treated by analysts as **ineligible under PM Wong’s stated COP-related criterion**. citeturn3view0turn4view0  
- The COP-linked implications were also discussed publicly in relation to **Faisal Manap** (though whether he is presently an MP is separate from the eligibility point). citeturn3view0turn5news32

## A realistic near-term wrinkle
WP is not legally required to nominate an LO, and commentators note WP may **delay** while it completes its **internal disciplinary inquiry** process. citeturn3view0turn4view0

entries.title: Singapore PM strips Singh of Leader of Opposition post
entries.snippet:
On January 15, 2026, Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong removed Pritam Singh from his position as Leader of the Opposition following Singh's conviction for lying to parliament. This unprecedented move came after a parliamentary vote declared Singh's conduct "dishonourable and unbecoming," deeming him unsuitable for the role. Wong emphasized the importance of maintaining the rule of law and parliamentary integrity.

Although the Leader of the Opposition role is not constitutionally mandated, it grants extra privileges, such as allowances, staff support, and access to confidential information. Wong has asked the Workers' Party to propose a replacement untainted by the scandal. Despite his removal from the post, Singh will remain a Member of Parliament and leader of the Workers' Party.

The conviction stems from Singh giving false testimony in 2021 regarding a former party member's fabricated parliamentary speech. Singh had become Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election. While political observers downplayed the practical impact of Singh’s removal, the Workers’ Party stated it will carefully consider Wong's request before responding.

entries.title: Singapore parliament to debate removing Leader of the Opposition after lying conviction
entries.snippet: Singapore's Parliament is set to debate the removal of Pritam Singh from his role as Leader of the Opposition following his conviction for lying to Parliament. The motion, introduced by Leader of the House and People’s Action Party (PAP) MP Indranee Rajah, cites Singh's "dishonourable and unbecoming" behavior as grounds for disqualification. Singh, who became Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election, was found guilty in 2025 of providing false testimony to a parliamentary committee in relation to a fellow Workers' Party member, Raeesah Khan. Although he received fines that allowed him to retain his parliamentary seat, an unsuccessful appeal resulted in Parliament now considering a response to his actions. Indranee stated that such behavior must not be tolerated in Singapore, emphasizing integrity in leadership. The conduct of Workers' Party leaders Sylvia Lim and Faisal Manap is also under scrutiny in connection to Singh’s case. The ruling PAP continues its dominance in Parliament, having won 87 out of 97 seats in the 2025 general election.

Although the Leader of the Opposition role is not constitutionally mandated, it grants extra privileges, such as allowances, staff support, and access to confidential information. Wong has asked the Workers' Party to propose a replacement untainted by the scandal. Despite his removal from the post, Singh will remain a Member of Parliament and leader of the Workers' Party.

The conviction stems from Singh giving false testimony in 2021 regarding a former party member's fabricated parliamentary speech. While political observers downplayed the practical impact of Singh’s removal, the Workers’ Party stated it will carefully consider Wong's request before responding.

metadata.reasoning_title: Explaining impact of LO vacancy on resources

thoughts.summary: Explaining delay effects on LO resources
thoughts.content: A delay in appointing a new Leader of the Opposition (LO) halts crucial LO-specific resources like salary, staff, office, and speaking time. These include a package around S$385k, staff allowances for additional assistants, and speaking priority during Parliament. Without an LO, these privileges are lost, though MPs continue receiving baseline allowances.

thoughts.summary: Clarifying resource impacts and costs of delay
thoughts.content: The LO’s resources, like staff and allowances, are personal—not party funds; although the party benefits indirectly. A delay reduces access to staff for research and parliamentary work. Some analysts, including Walid Jumblatt Abdullah, note that the main loss is the allowance and speaking time, but these are significant.

thoughts.summary: Responding concisely about LO resources
thoughts.content: To clarify: Until the new LO is appointed, WP forfeits LO-specific resources. These include the extra salary (double MP allowance), increased staffing allowances, office/meeting room, confidential briefings, and procedural advantages like first response and extra speaking time. WP MPs retain their baseline allowances and speaking rights.

parts:
You’re basically right: **if the LO post stays vacant, the LO-specific support doesn’t “sit with WP” by default — it sits with the office-holder.** So **any delay is an opportunity cost** in money, staffing bandwidth, access, and procedure.

What gets “stalled” while there’s no designated LO:

- **Extra allowance (salary)**: the LO is paid **double an elected MP’s allowance** (commonly cited as about **S$385,000/year**, inclusive of the MP allowance). citeturn1search23turn0search8  
- **Extra staffing support**: LO gets an **office + meeting room in Parliament**, a **dedicated secretary**, and allowances to hire **up to 3 additional legislative assistants** (on top of the baseline staffing support MPs already receive). citeturn0search8  
- **Confidential briefings/access**: LO receives **confidential briefings** on selected matters (national security/external relations; crisis/emergency situations). With no LO, there’s no designated recipient. citeturn0search8turn0news30  
- **Parliamentary “platform” advantages**: conventions like **first right of response** and **longer speaking time** accorded to the LO don’t automatically carry over to another WP MP unless an LO is appointed. citeturn1search23  

This is also why PM Wong explicitly said he hopes to receive a nomination soon **so the position “will not remain vacant for too long.”** citeturn0search16

One nuance: **WP MPs still remain MPs** with their normal parliamentary rights and baseline staffing support, so Parliament doesn’t “stop working” for the opposition. But the **incremental LO layer** (extra staff/time/access/allowance) is what gets paused until someone is designated. citeturn0search6turn0search8

supporting_websites.title: Singapore PM strips Singh of Leader of Opposition post
supporting_websites.snippet:
On January 15, 2026, Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong removed Pritam Singh from his position as Leader of the Opposition following Singh's conviction for lying to parliament. This unprecedented move came after a parliamentary vote declared Singh's conduct "dishonourable and unbecoming," deeming him unsuitable for the role. Wong emphasized the importance of maintaining the rule of law and parliamentary integrity.

Although the Leader of the Opposition role is not constitutionally mandated, it grants extra privileges, such as allowances, staff support, and access to confidential information. Wong has asked the Workers' Party to propose a replacement untainted by the scandal. Despite his removal from the post, Singh will remain a Member of Parliament and leader of the Workers' Party.

The conviction stems from Singh giving false testimony in 2021 regarding a former party member's fabricated parliamentary speech. Singh had become Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election. While political observers downplayed the practical impact of Singh’s removal, the Workers’ Party stated it will carefully consider Wong's request before responding.

entries.title: Singapore PM strips Singh of Leader of Opposition post
entries.snippet:
On January 15, 2026, Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong removed Pritam Singh from his position as Leader of the Opposition following Singh's conviction for lying to parliament. This unprecedented move came after a parliamentary vote declared Singh's conduct "dishonourable and unbecoming," deeming him unsuitable for the role. Wong emphasized the importance of maintaining the rule of law and parliamentary integrity.

Although the Leader of the Opposition role is not constitutionally mandated, it grants extra privileges, such as allowances, staff support, and access to confidential information. Wong has asked the Workers' Party to propose a replacement untainted by the scandal. Despite his removal from the post, Singh will remain a Member of Parliament and leader of the Workers' Party.

The conviction stems from Singh giving false testimony in 2021 regarding a former party member's fabricated parliamentary speech. Singh had become Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election. While political observers downplayed the practical impact of Singh’s removal, the Workers’ Party stated it will carefully consider Wong's request before responding.

entries.title: Singapore parliament to debate removing Leader of the Opposition after lying conviction
entries.snippet: Singapore's Parliament is set to debate the removal of Pritam Singh from his role as Leader of the Opposition following his conviction for lying to Parliament. The motion, introduced by Leader of the House and People’s Action Party (PAP) MP Indranee Rajah, cites Singh's "dishonourable and unbecoming" behavior as grounds for disqualification. Singh, who became Singapore's first official Leader of the Opposition after the 2020 general election, was found guilty in 2025 of providing false testimony to a parliamentary committee in relation to a fellow Workers' Party member, Raeesah Khan. Although he received fines that allowed him to retain his parliamentary seat, an unsuccessful appeal resulted in Parliament now considering a response to his actions. Indranee stated that such behavior must not be tolerated in Singapore, emphasizing integrity in leadership. The conduct of Workers' Party leaders Sylvia Lim and Faisal Manap is also under scrutiny in connection to Singh’s case. The ruling PAP continues its dominance in Parliament, having won 87 out of 97 seats in the 2025 general election.

parts:
If WP *does* nominate someone fairly soon, **Gerald Giam** looks like the single most likely pick.

Why I’d weight it that way:

- **Multiple analysts call Giam (and Dennis Tan) the frontrunners**, mainly on seniority + being trusted by WP leadership, and they single out Giam’s “veteran” status and visibility in Parliament. citeturn3view0  
- **He cleanly fits PM Wong’s stated constraint** (“not implicated in the earlier findings of the Committee of Privileges”). citeturn1view1turn3view0  
- He’s a **“continuity” choice**: senior enough to carry the LO resources/visibility without forcing an immediate leadership reshuffle inside WP (since LO doesn’t *have* to be the party secretary-general). citeturn3view0  

**Close #2: Dennis Tan.** He’s also explicitly named a frontrunner, but CNA notes he **sat in the Committee of Privileges** (not the same as being “implicated,” but it may complicate optics depending on how strictly one reads the “implicated” phrasing). citeturn3view0turn1view1  

If you want a rough subjective weighting (assuming WP fills it soon): **Giam ~45%**, **Dennis Tan ~35%**, **He Ting Ru ~15%**, **Jamus Lim ~5%**. The last two are plausible but (per the same analyst commentary) they’re not as consistently positioned as the top two. citeturn3view0
